title: 110_s2939
content: The Act titled "National Guard and Reserve Mental Health Access Act of 2008" implements the Yellow Ribbon Reintegration Program for National Guard and Reserve members. The Secretary of Defense must establish the Yellow Ribbon Reintegration Program for National Guard and Reserve members and their families within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness must submit a report on the program's implementation to the Senate and House Armed Services Committees within the same timeframe. The Yellow Ribbon Reintegration Program for National Guard and Reserve members and their families must be established within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness must submit a report on the program's implementation, including recommendations for improvement and additional resources needed. SEC. 3. JOINT PSYCHOLOGICAL HEALTH PROGRAM. The Secretary of Defense, through the Chief of the National Guard Bureau, is required to carry out a program to improve access to psychological health care for National Guard members and their families, enhance coordination in providing care during their transition to civilian life, and oversee assistance for National Guard members with mental illness and Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI). The Joint Psychological Health Program, overseen by the Chief of the National Guard Bureau, designates Directors of Psychological Health for the Army and Air National Guard. Each director must meet specific qualifications and expertise. The Director of Psychological Health under the Joint Psychological Health Program carries out duties as required by law or the Chief of the National Guard Bureau. The Program includes state networks of psychological health professionals to conduct programs and activities in each State, Territory, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. The Director overseeing the Joint Psychological Health Program in each State, Territory, the District of Columbia, or Puerto Rico is selected by the Chief of the National Guard Bureau based on psychology licensure or certification requirements. The Director serves under a contract and is responsible for coordinating and overseeing program activities. The Director of the Joint Psychological Health Program is responsible for coordinating and overseeing activities in the jurisdiction, working with agencies to develop a comprehensive plan for psychological needs, and informing National Guard members on accessing behavioral health services and education programs. The Director of the Joint Psychological Health Program oversees education and training programs for National Guard leadership on psychological health matters, coordinates programs to assist members and families in building psychological fitness, and coordinates psychological care during transitions. To improve access to psychological care for National Guard members and their families, coordination with State agencies and community-based behavioral health service providers is essential. Assessing the resource needs of these providers and coordinating with other psychological health programs are also key objectives. To improve access to psychological care for National Guard members and their families, coordination with State agencies and community-based behavioral health service providers is essential. This includes coordinating with other psychological health components of the reserve components of the Armed Forces, overseeing Department of Defense initiatives, participating in national and regional work groups, and conducting outreach and education efforts. The Chief of the National Guard Bureau will establish the National Guard Psychological Health Council for outreach and education on mental health issues, including PTSD, for National Guard members and their families. The National Guard Psychological Health Council, established by the Chief of the National Guard Bureau, oversees and coordinates the development of mental health programs, ensures national consistency, and advises on mental health issues for National Guard members and their families. The National Guard Psychological Health Council advises on psychological needs, disseminates best practices in behavioral health care, and develops standards for measuring success in providing services to National Guard members and their families. Collaboration with the National Guard Bureau is essential. The National Guard Bureau and Department of Defense collaborate in implementing the Program. Directors of Psychological Health work with Department of Veterans Affairs, Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, and State agencies. In collaboration with the Department of Defense, the National Guard Bureau implements the Joint Psychological Health Program. The term "Territory" is defined in section 101(1) of title 32, United States Code. $8,035,000 is authorized for the Department of Defense for fiscal year 2009 for the program. SEC. 4. Pilot programs on pre-deployment and post-deployment telemental health services for members of the National Guard and Reserve. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct pilot programs on providing mental health services to National Guard and Reserve members through telemental health technologies before and after deployment to assess their feasibility and effectiveness. The programs will be carried out in consultation with the Chief of the National Guard Bureau. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct pilot programs in coordination with other government agencies to provide mental health services to National Guard and Reserve members. The programs will be carried out in selected locations, with an emphasis on serving members in rural areas. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct pilot programs utilizing telemental health technologies proven effective for mental health services to National Guard and Reserve members in rural areas. A report to Congress is due within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Secretary of Defense will submit a report to Congress on pilot programs for mental health services for National Guard and Reserve members. The report will include details on the types of services provided, telemental health technologies used, the number of members served, and the outcomes. $2,005,000 is authorized for pilot programs in fiscal year 2009. In fiscal year 2009, $2,005,000 is allocated for pilot programs to provide mental health services for National Guard and Reserve members. SEC. 5. ANTI-STIGMA CAMPAIGN PROMOTING MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES FOR NATIONAL GUARD AND RESERVE MEMBERS RETURNING FROM DEPLOYMENT AND THEIR FAMILIES. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will jointly conduct an outreach program to reduce stigma around seeking mental health services for National Guard and Reserve members returning from deployment and their families. Coordination with the Chief of the National Guard Bureau and the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration will be ensured. The Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct programs to reduce stigma for National Guard and Reserve members seeking mental health services. $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2009 for this purpose.
